stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body: yes the exif is there after loading a file into gimp but not there after export. The data from the original file can be still be read in gimp but the output file to windows has no data and if you load that exported file back into gimp you see no data.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body:
the problem is with the word "PENTAX"  all Capitals (or maybe just part of that word). Pentax cameras up until the K5 just have the word "PENTAX" as The manufacturer or Camera Make field of the exif. later models have  "RICOH IMAGING COMPANY, LTD" in the camera make field, so the problem doesn't occur. 
Edit that field to anything other than PENTAX or just remove it all together and there is no problem. 
Take an image file (JPG )from any other manufacturer and edit Camera Make in the exif to be PENTAX and load it into gimp and then export and it will fail to export the exif data with an exported image 

I have used K30, K20D and optio E40 files and the same happens to all, they all have the word "PENTAX" in the Camera Make field If I change field to anything else they export the exif data ok.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body: I see some have changed the exif to of a different manufacturers file (canon etc) to PENTAX and had the exif data export ok.  That seems different to what I found but I only tried this once with a Nikon jpeg file, I thought it failed but I'll have to recheck this.

events.target_title: stripped exif data if Camera make is "PENTAX"

note.body:
just for clarity on my results
On earlier Pentax Camera (eg istDS, K100) Camera make = "PENTAX Corporation" 
Then changed (eg K30, K50, K5) Camera make = "PENTAX" 
Later models ( K3, K70, K1 )  Camera make = "RICOH IMAGING COMPANY, LTD"

exif fails on both PENTAX & PENTAX Corporation for out of camera JPGs

Out of Camera JPGs on "PENTAX Corporation" files = Fail  { origin/Program name = *istDS  Ver 2.02 }

For "PENTAX Corporation" PEF raw file using UFRaw and exported to a JPEG then loaded & Exported from gimp exif is OK. { Origin/Program name = GIMP 2.4.6 }

Changing any part of the word "PENTAX" (eg pENTAX or PENTAx) causes the exif to output correctly so I believe not a part of the word or combination of some letters causing issue.

I mean that `INSTALL` is outdated:

* Support was added for `meson` ten months ago: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/eog/commit/b55f66560e6eff902b08346198ceb15b5500aed3
* Support was removed for `autotools` eight months ago for the specific reason "To avoid the burden of maintaining multiple build systems": https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/eog/commit/b2dcab7e582c5b9e3d6131361b074bf215bb40fe
* `INSTALL` (https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/eog/blob/master/INSTALL) is thirteen years old and describes how to use `autotools`, which is no longer supported

events.target_title: GtkTrayIcon has no background on X11

note.body:
Unfortunately we had to revert the fix in Arch because several people reported crashes caused by X BadMatch'ing when using a display compositor.

Based on the reddit thread bellow, it appears that `pattern == gdk_x11_get_parent_relative_pattern()` is true in cases other than the intended one.

```
(firefox:3905): Gdk-WARNING **: 01:20:23.199: Can't set ParentRelative background for window 0x2c0003c, depth of parent doesn't match

(firefox:3905): Gdk-ERROR **: 01:20:32.360: The program 'firefox' received an X Window System error.
This probably reflects a bug in the program.
The error was 'BadMatch (invalid parameter attributes)'.
```

References:

* https://www.reddit.com/r/archlinux/comments/a5l38q/
* https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/61049
* https://bugs.archlinux.org/task/61050

Since compositing is enabled and Firefox doesn't use tray icons anyway, is it possible that the pattern returned by `cairo_pattern_create_rgba` in `gdk_x11_get_parent_relative_pattern` is reused elsewhere?

events.target_title: Gnome Books sorting/progressive loading doesn't correctly place books without titles at start-up

note.body:
It does look like it doesn't have a title based on the display, but Tracker seemingly has the information:

```
$ tracker info Documents/ebooks/Novels/AoS_ageofmyth_pantheon.epub |grep "nie:title\|nfo:fileName"
  'nie:title' = 'Pantheon'
  'nfo:fileName' = 'AoS_ageofmyth_pantheon.epub'
$ tracker info Documents/ebooks/Software/aboutface.epub |grep "nie:title\|nfo:fileName"
  'nie:title' = 'About Face'
  'nfo:fileName' = 'aboutface.epub'
```

The only discernible differences from looking inside the files are that the AoS book contains an OEBPS directory rather than an OPS directory (but the `META-INF/container.xml` references that correctly) and the AoS book contains `META-INF/com.apple.ibooks.display-options.xml`. Both `content.opf` files contain one `<dc:title>` and at least one `<dc:creator>`.

[Edit] Actually, things have changed. That AoS book is now in the right place with the right information, despite not having changed since I downloaded it in April! However, another book with the same "no author line" situation seems *not* to show an `nie:title` value in Tracker. So, that probably is the cause. But I don't know why Tracker would know some information and not others when the books have been there for MONTHS!

This does seem to be the same as #1437 submitted by Othmar Marti.

I also mentioned it on Gimplearn forum on 25 March 2018 as a possible bug

>  gimplearn.net/viewtopic.php/Metadata-Keywords-?t=1336

**I ALSO HAVE THIS PROBLEM WITH JPG'S**
I was previously working with Ubuntu 16.04 LTS and recently saved everything and reloaded fresh install with Ubuntu 18.10 which loaded shotwell 0.30.1
On re-importing my photos, (many thousands) shotwell was hanging for ages, even after restart, when it eventually loaded all photos have virtually every tag I assigned.
I then removed the shotwell folder in .local and re-impoted a small number of photos, the tags now bear no resemblance to the photos. Almost all photos have all the tags from all the other photos but not all of them. There seems to be no pattern that I can find.

I have also tried the same photos on another partition which uses Ubuntu 16.04 LTS with shotwell 0.22.0 and they have the correct tags, which is also reported correctly by exiftool so it does not appear that the jpg files have been corrupted.

I will try to see if I can find a pattern to the problem by loading a few photos with different tags one by one.

events.target_title: RAW CR2 files with wrong tags after database rebuild

note.body:
**UPDATE - MAJOR PROBLEM WITH TAGS**
My previous use of shotwell was with 0.22.0 under Ubuntu 16.04 LTS.
This behaviour happens with 0.30.1 – “Celle” under Ubuntu 18.10. I do not know when this behaviour started having not tried anything between these versions.

I hope the following example (easily reproduced) helps in identifying the problem.


I have cleared out shotwell library (deleted shotwell in .local/share)
I created 4 different directories with one sample photo (with tags as shown below) in each directory - so 4 photos and 12 tags with no photo having more than 4 tags.
I then imported (in place) each of the 4 directories separately.

pic 1 tags A,B,C

pic 2 tags D

pic 3 tags E,F,G,C

pic 4 tags H,I,J,C

The 1st pic imported correctly with its 3 tags (ABC).
the 2nd pic imported with its tag (D) and also incorrectly inherited all existing tags (ABC).
The 3rd pic imported with its tags (EFGC) and also incorrectly inherited all existing tags (ABD).
The 4th pic imported with its tags (HIJC) and incorrectly inherited all other existing tags (ABDEFG) (All 12 tags attached!!!)

The result is that each photo has whatever tags it contains itself and also seems to inherit incorrectly all other tags known by shotwell at that time. The actual JPG files do not seem to get updated (thank God).
None of the earlier imported photos inherited any tags created after they were imported (correct!).

This could also explain why shotwell seems to lock up with thousands of imported photos, each containing a few tags. The last photo imported would apparently have thousands of tags assigned to it.
In my case with around 12,000 photos shotwell takes around 20 minutes to get started with 4gb of ram using 1 of the 4 CPUs at 100% during this time. Trying to select photos by a tag sends it back to sleep again for a similar time... Totally unusable.

events.target_title: Tag problem with imported photos
Tag problem with imported photos

note.body:
**UPDATE**
I have just tried to replicate this with clean images (all metadata removed with `exiftool -all= *.jpg`) and then importing them into shotwell 0.30.1 re-creating the tags, then clearing out shotwell and re-importing the images, the tags are all correct!

On further investigation it would appear that this fault only occurs if the images have had their metadata updated by digikam (I have also seen strange behaviour after modification by gimp but that was due to a problem with gimp https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/2192).

I have no idea why this happens in this instance because the metadata info in the files looks ok!

I can supply some sample photos if required.

events.target_title: Tag problem with imported photos

note.body:
**MORE INFORMATION**

I have created 4 simple jpgs (attached).![Pic1](/uploads/1eb5092de485c1e83c869b0731d32047/Pic1.jpg)![Pic2](/uploads/59dbaa0979ca650e3e6db6f6722def2f/Pic2.jpg)![Pic3](/uploads/3e9e41b2ae5a859bdbefdaaa3820d520/Pic3.jpg)![Pic4](/uploads/59b59c12b46b7b56061fb102f08de269/Pic4.jpg) Pic1-Pic4 with the tags previously mentioned.

Also attached are txt files of the associated metadata as output from exiftool for each of the above jpegs.
![Pic1-a.txt](/uploads/c24477bca295169baa9c121150feae02/Pic1-a.txt)[Pic2-a.txt](/uploads/79135d8fbbfc47c8007ced8228a2c958/Pic2-a.txt)[Pic3-a.txt](/uploads/2ae85b522612b84bb49618c8638558ea/Pic3-a.txt)[Pic4-a.txt](/uploads/cf9518a87f14a9a74c3b62afe08d460e/Pic4-a.txt)


The jpegs were then imported into Digikam (which ads some further metadata)
the resulting jpeg files are:-![Pic1-b](/uploads/22fb37ce64ea800df53adf696fb839b9/Pic1-b.jpg)![Pic2-b](/uploads/cc847d95913c8a51473f59c5196b874f/Pic2-b.jpg)![Pic3-b](/uploads/569fe720a06a579b461ae5c4ba7f10d8/Pic3-b.jpg)![Pic4-b](/uploads/d095ea84877dcb9459bbdde866ccc163/Pic4-b.jpg)

and also the associated metadata as output from exiftool for these files.
[Pic1-b.txt](/uploads/eba6dd89084a8c6cf2f5320ac4ec7e1f/Pic1-b.txt)[Pic2-b.txt](/uploads/fcb339bb66eae73549b0d481cb2a3910/Pic2-b.txt)[Pic3-b.txt](/uploads/b5a8a166d84d7b678bb5fdd65c3a0bda/Pic3-b.txt)[Pic4-b.txt](/uploads/6fc128f67fd901273b454911ef815b1c/Pic4-b.txt).

Importing these udpated jpegs into shotwell 0.30.1 results in the image having every tag that shotwell knows of attached to the photo. This behaviour does not happen when importing into shotwell 0.22.0 

It would appear that the problem for (Pic1) metadata is the line containing:-

`Categories                      : <Categories><Category Assigned="1">C</Category><Category Assigned="1">A</Category><Category Assigned="1">B</Category></Categories>`

and similar entries for each of the other images.

Removing this data from all image files prior to importing into shotwell 0.30.1 prevents this problem (but I don't know what the side effects of removing this are).

I have found that by issuing the command `exiftool -Categories= *.jpg` will remove this problem line for all jpg files in the current directory enabling them to be imported into shotwell correctly, but this is a very labour intensive workaround when images are in multiple directories.

Given all the above info I believe it should be very simple to fix this problem with shotwell, especially as the problem didn't exist in 0.22.0.

regards
Brian

events.target_title: Metadata Keywords corruption

note.body:
Any progress on this outstanding issue?

The problem still exists and is also present in Gimp 2.10.8 (with Ubuntu 16.10).

events.target_title: Metadata Keywords corruption

note.body:
@Jehan Many thanks for your reply. I wish I was able to help with this but sadly my software skills are nowhere near the level required.
I suspect that the problem lies within the data format of the Keywords metadata, in that Gimp seems to read it as a "string" and sees only the first keyword in the list when in fact it is a comma delimited list.
For example an image may have 3 keywords (A,B,C) which are 3 separate keywords or tags (below reported by exiv2 -pa Pic1.jpg command:-
`Exif.Image.Software                          Ascii      16  Shotwell 0.30.1
Iptc.Application2.Keywords                   String      1  A
Iptc.Application2.Keywords                   String      1  B
Iptc.Application2.Keywords                   String      1  C
Iptc.Application2.Program                    String      8  Shotwell
Iptc.Application2.ProgramVersion             String      6  0.30.1
Xmp.xmp.Label                                XmpText     1  C
Xmp.dc.subject                               XmpBag      3  A, B, C
`
which is seen by Gimp from Image/Metadata/View metadata as:-
![image](/uploads/98964a22a08ffe640e7fecd4b22746cc/image.png)
although Image/Metadata/Edit shows:-
![image](/uploads/270c2e8b6b67b8f4b7bdedf6d0fe21c6/image.png)
which on the face of it looks correct but in fact writes this as a "string" rather than a comma delimited list such that the metadata in the image is now one keyword "A,B,C" including commas, rather than "A","B","C" as it was previously, ie 3 separate keywords delimited by commas.

I wish I was able to provide a patch or something but as I've already mentioned that is beyond my skill level and any attempt to do so would probably totally begger things up!

I will gladly assist in any way I can with someone of a higher skill level than me.

Have a happy new year.

Is there a way we could have a healthy middle ground to this issue? Specifically, I would like to be able to use dynamic work spaces still with this plugin, but would like it so that some windows are automatically created into the 'last' workspace option. This way, some windows are opened unobtrusively from the user and can be reorganized later. You could even make it a check box that says `Open in first available dynamic workspace` which means you could specify a number and it will always open in the first available workspace up until there are x# of workspaces available. 

Additionally, as @AbuMaia has said, it would be nice for AMW to revert back to standard behavior once the rules are no longer necessary (i.e. all available windows are closed.)

events.target_title: Mouse cursor disappears in overview

note.body:
I am not entirely convinced that this is Gnome Shell related.

I can reliably reproduce this issue by simply letting the cursor stay put for 1-2 minutes on either of my 2 monitors.

- Scenario 1
   1. I let the cursor stay put for ~2 minutes on monitor A, over the desktop background.
   2. After 2 minutes, I move the cursor over to monitor B. It remains visible over shell elements. It disappears over applications.

- Scenario 2
  1. I let the cursor stay put for ~2 minutes on monitor A, over an application.
  2. After 2 minutes, I move the cursor to the desktop or a shell element, it disappears. It remains visible over applications.
  3. I move the cursor over to monitor B. It remains visible over applications, it disappears over shell elements.

I've also noticed that in both scenarios the cursor becomes invisible over maximized Gnome Terminal, but not over maximized Sublime Text, nor over unmaximized Gnome Terminal. I'm not sure what's going on there. I can't reproduce that part reliably.

To bring back the cursor everywhere, a change of cursor sprite seems to be enough (for example triggered by dragging a window).

```
Linux 5.2.0-2-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 5.2.9-1 (2019-08-18) x86_64 GNU/Linux
Intel Corporation HD Graphics 630 (rev 04) with driver i915
GNOME Shell 3.30.2 (Wayland)
```

note.body:
You can cross-compile VICE on Linux for Windows, using Fedora. I did that once since Fedora provides Gtk/GLib mingw packages and Debian does not. Actually doing a `make bindist` will fail since that script is Debian-based.

What I usually do when hacking on VICE in Windows with msys2 is to copy all files in data/C64 and data/DRIVES to, for example, ~/alldata-c64, and then run `x64sc.exe -directory ~/alldata-c64`, that should at least make the ROMs, keymaps and palettes available. Loading the gresource with custom icons/logos and loading the CBM font will still fail though (but those are just cosmetics, not required for proper operation).

I hope this helps a bit. And thanks for figuring out what the bug is.

events.target_title: Cannot get nautilus debug log without debug messages from dependencies

note.body:
I've created a script that adds `G_LOG_DOMAIN` before the first `#include` of every .c file: [define-g-log-domain.sh](/uploads/714320df69656babea15031cf2d74c7d/define-g-log-domain.sh). (It creates two redefinition warnings in the build.)

As domain name, the file name gets reused. This fits the task description, although we should also consider limiting the number of domains. It strikes a balance of being able to show only nautilus messages while not being too fine grained. With one domain per file, there would be quite a few domains (currently 109). To get all nautilus related messages, one would need to construct a very long colon-separated `G_MESSAGES_DEBUG` environment variable.

An alternative is taking only the first two hyphen separated file name components as domain name, i.e. `nautilus-canvas-item.c` and `nautilus-canvas-view.c` both get `nautilus-canvas` defined as log domain. This already reduces the number quite a bit, but still requires laborious construction of `G_MESSAGES_DEBUG`. I guess subdomain approach is only good for targeted debugging of one component, not so much for tracing bugs.

Tracing could be better supported with another alternative: setting only one domain in a `-DG_LOG_DOMAIN=nautilus` C flag.

I could even imagine a hybrid approach, where a configure flag toggles the file specific domain:

    #ifndef ENABLE_GLOBAL_LOG_DOMAIN
    #define G_LOG_DOMAIN "nautilus-canvas"
    #endif

It would also toggle the C flag `-DG_LOG_DOMAIN`.

Glib docs don't seem opinionated which approach to choose.

events.target_title: G_MESSAGES_DEBUG doesn't allow filtering by superdomain

note.body: Compatibility could be preserved by adding simple glob matching, i.e. `G_MESSAGES_DEBUG=bloatpad-*` would match any bloatpad domain.

events.target_title: Cannot get nautilus debug log without debug messages from dependencies

note.body:
So, the glib issue is closed. What would be your preferred way forward?

* Custom log handler – I would make a thin adapter of the standard, just adding glob matching.
* build flag switch for the hybrid approach
* nautilus and nautilus-file domain – this would be quickest

note.body:
I'm listening scroll event for some widget in our app. Does your change mean that we'll have to know which kind of device is used to remove `GDK_SMOOTH_SCROLL_MASK` first in order to have `GDK_SCROLL_LEFT/RIGHT/UP/DOWN` events ?

I don't see the point of emulating a smooth scroll for device that don't offer that possibility. I'd rather specifically ask for emulation (for the unknown case where it could be useful) than looking for a device type before asking for events.

Also think about case where scroll up/down with the mouse wheel could be used to scroll a Gtk::ScrolledWindow horizontally (yes, that can occur, we did it). Handling emulation is more difficult than handling more event type (in my case of course).

events.target_title: GDK W32: send both smooth and discrete scrolling events

note.body:
@Ede123 

> If you only want "real" scroll events

Thanks for the info, however I may not understand how devices actually works in Gtk3. In my understanding, device like touch pad and touch screen (depending on the driver) would mainly send `GDK_SCROLL_SMOOTH` event, and possibly emulated `GDK_SCROLL_LEFT/RIGHT/UP/DOWN` event. Mouses however would rather do the opposite.

I'm sure some people like me will use alternatively their mouse + a touch pad (or touch screen) connected at the same time. If I want to take the best out of all the connected device that can be used "at the same time", I'll have to set `GDK_SCROLL_MASK | GDK_SMOOTH_SCROLL_MASK`. Then how can I tell Gtk to send me the preferred choice of scrolling event for each device ?

Your comment above tells me that if I ask for `GDK_SCROLL_MASK | GDK_SMOOTH_SCROLL_MASK`, I'll only receive `GDK_SMOOTH_SCROLL_MASK` from any device, but if I remove `GDK_SMOOTH_SCROLL_MASK` from the mask, then I'll only receive `GDK_SCROLL_MASK`. So they are mutually exclusive now and `GDK_SMOOTH_SCROLL_MASK` is preferred over `GDK_SCROLL_MASK` if they are both set.

Of course, as you said, I could only use `GDK_SCROLL_SMOOTH` events, and read `delta_x` and `delta_y` to get the scroll cardinal direction of my mouse wheel, which actually it send me `delta_y` = +/-3 for `GDK_SCROLL_SMOOTH` events. How can I know if delta is a real smooth scroll and be used in Pixel, or an emulated one and used as a number of line ?

Provide a way to disambiguate/tag/color/rename tabs and windows

note.body:
Thanks, António, for your feedback!

I'll provide you a simple example on why even with windows the issue is still there. The data I'm working on are in the folders like

    /home/me/Projects/my-project/current_revision/debugging/yyyy-mm-dd/data/data_source/some_category/number

and the trailing folders (data/data_source/some_category/number) are very often the same, and file names in directory `number` are actually the same in all possible `number` folders (which are like 00, 01, 02...). This stems from the fact that I am analyzing few data sets with different algorithms tested in different conditions, and files and folders are 99% of the times very similar in name.

Locations such the one above, are often trimmed to the last folders (e.g. data/data_source/some_category/number), and unless the window is big enough, I get to see the parts of the path that are ambiguous.

I can imagine this is a very, very remote case, but it is still happening, and there is often not enough context to disambiguate. I often find myself pressing Ctrl+L and inspecting the path to find what I am looking at.

I agree coloring is not the best options, but I think some kind of window-level path disambiguation could be put in place as well (e.g., show different parts of the paths).

events.target_title: po: minor updates for Norwegain bokmaal
Make text of error dialogs copyable

note.body:
Something I always liked about Gtk apps in Linux over other what other UIs do (e.g. MS Windows) is that I was able to copy and paste text from error dialogs. At first it was surprising, but later I found that to be very helpful when you want to search a error message in the Internet, and could sometimes be the difference between investigating an issue or dropping the application altogether.

It's also quite useful in the cases where the message contains a long file path that you may want to use in another application to debug the problem, or when you want to share the message with someone (you can paste text instead of using screenshots).

In the end, my surprise about this feature existing turned out into surprise about how come no other systems had thought of this before. It's actually simple and useful!

Sure, it's not a deal-breaker, but I'm a bit sad to see this feature going away (or rather get hidden).

note.body:
Here's what it would look like if I only added `!important` (no padding change):

![16px](/uploads/0d067dba7d0c2db1c3b1a52827f5dff3/16px.png)

Ditto, but also increasing the padding correspondingly (14px):

![16px+14px_padding](/uploads/66be512320b5e6ab74fc1cdb2a4aac61/16px+14px_padding.png)

Another option: `icon-size: 28px !important; padding: 8px;`

![28px](/uploads/4757de0619ef8277b80c0895e333cfbc/28px.png)

Sticking to 32px as a common icon size: `icon-size: 32px !important; padding: 6px;`

![32px](/uploads/d846f2b13c97e0e18929f484c1ad7077/32px.png)

note.body:
I've updated the MR to adopt the last option (32px icon-size + 6px padding) as 32px is a widely used icon size (16px looks too small for a 48px wide cover; not sure if 24px is a better choice though:
![24px](/uploads/4287c95db188a952b9071c9df8dae37e/24px.png)).

Non-16px symbolic icon might seem inconsistent, but the MPRIS section itself looks different compared to other notifications:

![mpris-vs-notifications](/uploads/d25bd66e753ae9ac47f97bba8556d68e/mpris-vs-notifications.png)

events.target_title: crashes when trying to play any song

note.body:
i have confirmed that GNOME Music crashes when starting to play if

```bash
gsettings get org.gnome.desktop.interface enable-animations
```

returns false. to fix it, replace the _update_timeout in gnomemusic.widgets.smoothscale with

```python
    def _update_timeout(*Argument_Tuple):
        """Update the duration for self._timeout
        Sets the period of self._timeout to a value small enough to make
        the slider SmoothScale move smoothly based on the current song
        duration and scale length.
        """
        Instance, = Argument_Tuple
        if Instance._timeout:
            GLib.source_remove(Instance._timeout)
        if Instance.get_realized() and not Instance._player.duration == None and Instance._player.duration > 0:
            Padding = Instance.get_style_context().get_padding(Gtk.StateFlags.NORMAL)
            Width = Instance.get_allocated_width() - Padding.right - Padding.left
            if Width > 0:
                Instance._timeout = GLib.timeout_add(min(1000 * Instance._player.duration // Width, 1000), Instance._update_position_callback)
                return
        Instance._timeout = GLib.timeout_add(1, Instance._update_timeout)
```

events.target_title: Cache last viewed pages

note.body:
Even if this issue is very old (from now 13 years), it still seems to be active and.. unfortunately open.
I may have an idea of the cause for this problem, 
it seems that evince does not honor the "org.gnome.Evince page-cache-size" option, usually found with dconf in "/org/gnome/evince/".

My guess comes from Atril (a fork of Evince), in which this very option works as intended.
In both application I had in the beginning "50 MB" as default. In both cases, a not optimized PDF or just a big PDF would reload initial pages again, after scrolling down and up again.

With the "page-cache-size" set to "400 MB" in both applications, Atril keeps the cached pages far longer and no reloads happens in this case. But Evince had the same urge to reload everything. Unlike Atril, Evince still only used about 50-60 MB memory.

I run Evince 3.30.0

note.body:
The GTK-Messages are normal and occur for many GTK-based snaps. The parse_iso_codes warning is specific to the GIMP snap. None of these messages should affect the running of GIMP, so the cause of your problem is not shown by the log messages.

Are you able to run other GTK-based snaps without issue? It might be advisable to open a thread on the [snapcraft forum](https://forum.snapcraft.io/) with as much detail as you can pull together, including the output of `snap version`. Please also tag me in the post, if you create one, with `@daniel` in the body of your message so that I am notified about it. Posting on the snapcraft forum will allow the problem to be thought through and checked by people who work on the snap system in addition to myself, the packager of the GIMP snap.

I do not think that the problem is a GIMP issue and thus this issue tracker might not be the best place to diagnose.

The output of the command that @lillolollo suggested will also be useful to see.

events.target_title: Gimp Can Not Load an Existing png File Created by my Delayed Screenshot starter

note.body: This is a byproduct of the confinement that the snapd enforces on strictly confined snaps. `/tmp` is unfortunately unique per snap and so the GIMP snap cannot access the path from the host system. Can I ask that you create a thread on [forum.snapcraft.io](https://forum.snapcraft.io/) to highlight the issue? Maybe by creating more noise, we can try to get the snapd developers to magic a way for processes like this to work out of the box.

Should a pair of terminfo capabilities be added for start/stop overline?
Should a pair of terminfo capabilities be added for start/stop overline?

note.body:
Oh well... Xterm is one that doesn't know what overline is, so I guess it's a doomed idea.

Still, if feels a bit lazy we don't explicitly advertise what we support through what seems to be the "official" way to do so. I'd totally like to try to add support for that in xterm, BTW, so, at least, adding it there would make sense.

This whole thing started with me wanting to add overline as a style for the status line on tmux and I followed quite a few white rabbits, drank suspicious stuff and had types of cake I'd normally avoid on my way here. I spend most of my time on a corporate laptop with Apple's Terminal.app (I know - there's zero chance of me convincing Apple to add a feature) and iTerm (after digging a bit into the code, with some incentive from the author, I must say there's also zero chance of me managing to do that). I guess I'll have to just add a horrendous literal "\033[53m" to tmux source, propose a patch and pray for the best.

Now that I mention it, it would look quite nice on c3270 and Minicom.

events.target_title: DECDWL/DECDHL (double width/height) support
DECDWL/DECDHL (double width/height) support

note.body:
Sorry for the misunderstanding.

Even though I mostly use tmux, a lot of people use things like Terminator and tiling window managers with plain terminal windows. Those people may be able to benefit from DECDWL/DECDHL.

In any case, I wouldn't give this a high priority. So few terminals support it that almost nobody use these features. The last time I saw it was at Blockbuster Video, while looking over the counter and observing the DVD rental UI on a physical VT terminal.

events.target_title: DECDWL/DECDHL (double width/height) support

note.body:
Inside tmux I can't even do italics unless I change TERM to something more flexible than "screen".

I would be totally OK with some glitches for copying text from the screen as text. There is already a lot of broken promises between terminals, clipboards, and GUI apps (it's pretty rare to copy rich text from a terminal screen and see the fonts, bolds, italics, underlines, and colors go along with the text when it's pasted into, say, an e-mail).

I also believe we can give up anything graphical - an imaginary sane approach, or insane ones such as sixels or Tek 4010 - that would work under tmux, at least for now and, most likely, forever.

Again, I opened this ticket as a question - should we pursue this idea and, if we choose to, how would we do so without too much long-term pain? I think its implementation - since it changes character width and presentation, would be something close to how people have been doing sixels (as they too change width and presentation). There is some support for sixels in software and it's handy for quickly plotting graphs from the command line.

On this last thing, there is probably ancient software that uses DECDWL/DECDHL and we just don't see it because our terminals don't render it. They may look a bit broken but, since it's ancient - and probably niche - software, nobody really cares enough to figure out why. If, however, a feature gets mainstream support, we'll end up writing software to use it the same way I can easily imagine myself using 2x3 smoothed mosaics to draw rolling area charts or to replace the misuse of braille chars.

BTW, implementing at least double width in tmux with the same approach @klamonte mentioned seems doable, and since tmux knows where the pane borders are, it would not suffer from the same fate a faithful terminal-level implementation would. But this is a discussion for the tmux developer list.

events.target_title: DECDWL/DECDHL (double width/height) support

note.body:
Thanks, @egmontkob. I completely understand and agree this is not one of the top million more useful terminal features we could direct our efforts to.

For the sake of the last remaining question about how this did/does/should behave if someone is insane enough to actually do it, I ran an experiment.

Since physical VT series terminals don't easily resize their screens to different shapes, I relief on the next best thing when it comes to archaic tech, xterm. It seems to think that the line continues at the same character width the original screen was before the line was widened (makes sense at 80 and 132 column modes), doesn't wrap the double-width text (rather lets it vanish into oblivion) and continues with normal text as soon as it has to get to the next line. The result is horrid, if, one would hope, an accurate replication of the historic behavior.

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
I just ran into this issue on my Fedora 28 system. Another existing application this change broke is the command line Google Drive client (https://github.com/odeke-em/drive). Since Google Apps files (e.g., docs, sheets, etc.) aren't downloadable, the default behavior of the application is export some "equivalent" versions in a directory (e.g., a PDF or ODS version of the document) and to create a ".desktop" link file.

For example:
Desktop Entry]
Icon=application-vnd.google-apps.spreadsheet
Name=Rowing Time and Rate Averager
Type=Link
URL=https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/<snip>/edit?usp=drivesdk

So, irrespective of whether ".desktop" files should be handled in their full glory by nautilus, removing support for "Type=Link" desktop files seems to have broken applications used by a significant number of people.

events.target_title: Solution for Type=Link .desktop files?

note.body:
@antoniof thanks for your reply. For the time being, I've added a nautilus script that parses the .desktop file and invokes chrome.

Regarding your comments:

(1) At least on my Fedora 28 system, .desktop files do not seem to open in a text editor. I'm not sure what app is opening them, but it just reports an error.

(2) One feature of the .desktop files that I suspect would be missing from an HTML redirect is the ability to associate an icon with the link. In the case of the "drive-google" tool, docs, spreadsheets, etc. display the expected icon.

(3) If the app was to be changed to generate a different format, it would be easy to create new app-specific extensions and associate a handling program and icon with them. In other words "my_doc_name.google-sheet-link" would be associated with the google-sheets icon and would be handled by a tiny application that invoked the user's web browser. That is, of course, less general than the HTML redirect solution. On the other hand, the HTML redirect solution has security problems of its own.

(4) I still feel that breaking backward compatibility is a mistake. People shouldn't have to rewrite or replace applications that have worked for years. I do understand the security concerns about "Type=Application" ".desktop" files. Those are sufficiently serious to justify removing support for them (or adding a registry of "allowed" applications, etc).

In summary, I get that ".desktop" files are an odd fit for Nautilus, and would support addressing their security concerns. I would also support deprecating ".desktop" file support in Nautilus. On the other hand, I think the mechanism is widely enough used that removing it altogether is a mistake.

That's my two cents!

note.body: Found the problem. I did a little searching and realized that the looking glass on my screenshots is correctly positioned on its "hiddenY" value. The problem was that the opening y animation to bring it down wasn't running. Seems like updating the extension "Impatience" brought the `St.get_slow_down_factor` to 0, which ended up with a 0 division for the animation time of the looking glass. Reverted the "Impatience" setting to a non 0 value and now it works correctly... Sorry about that!

note.body:
I tried a few different combinations to identify the edge case. **Bottom line: It appears that this may no longer be an issue in the latest nightly.** I don't know what your ticket workflow is, but this ticket can probably be marked as FIXED/RESOLVED.

These are the different combinations: 

# V0.28.3: Quote in Dir Name Under Monitored "Pictures" Directory
Shotwell wants to keep all of my pictures in a single directory (set in preferences). In my case, this is `~/Pictures`. If I create a directory called `~/Pictures/John's Photos` and add a new photo to it, Shotwell will detect the addition at runtime and add it to my library. If I navigate here in Shotwell and right click the photo, **the file manager loads as expected**.

# V0.28.3: Quote in Dir Name Imported In Place
In actuality, I keep most of my photos in different directories and use the "Import in Place" feature. For one example, I have a `~/sync-photos` directory. If I create a directory called `~/sync-photos/John's Photos`, add a new photo to it, and (re)import `~/sync-photos`, Shotwell will detect the addition add it to my library. If I navigate here in Shotwell and right click the photo, **the error message is shown** (See my initial write-up).

# Nightly V0.31.0.2018-09-17: Quote in Dir Name Under Monitored "Pictures" Directory
Following the same steps as above, **the file manager loads as expected**.

# Nightly V0.31.0.2018-09-17: Quote in Dir Name Imported In Place
Following the same steps as above, **the file manager loads as expected**.

events.target_title: Do not disclose user credentials when passing them through D-Bus

note.body: From a security PoV this is basic security by obscurity and effectively pointless - as you noted earlier Milan. In this case you are simply XORing each byte with a fixed value and then base64 encoding it - since the source code is public anyone can easily find this out and hence easily decode it - the only way to do this securely would be to have the DBus peers negotiate a session key and encrypt it properly using a proper encryption function - so I don't think there is any point adding this faux-encryption in this case.

events.target_title: Installation broken on Linux Mint
Installation broken on Linux Mint

note.body:
No because it is not related to Ubuntu directly but rather meld (this project) on Ubuntu. Nothing the Ubuntu guys could do about that.

To put it another way: The installation seems to assume to much about the OS and one of that assumptions does not hold on Ubuntu. So it is a bug in the installation not in Ubuntu.

As you see from above there are 3 parts: 

1. Assuming `/usr/lib/python<major.minor>/dist-packages` is in the python path
2. Configuring with a default `/usr` prefix but installing into `/usr/local` prefix
3. No pip support.

events.target_title: Installation broken on Linux Mint

note.body:
It seems to be more complicated than that:

`python3 setup.py install --prefix=/usr/local` does only partially work. It fails at runtime due to missing icons 

>   File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/meld/gutterrendererchunk.py", line 46, in load
    return icon_theme.load_icon(icon_name, LINE_HEIGHT, 0)

What I did now is: `./setup.py install --prefix=/usr && mv /usr/lib/python3.5/site-packages/meld* /usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages` which seems to work

Note the value of `sys.path`: `['', '/usr/lib/python35.zip', '/usr/lib/python3.5', '/usr/lib/python3.5/plat-x86_64-linux-gnu', '/usr/lib/python3.5/lib-dynload', '/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages', '/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages']`

events.target_title: Installation broken on Linux Mint

note.body: Yes it is Mint 18.3. I guess there is a significant difference to Ubuntu that I missed?

events.target_title: Fractional scaling support

note.body: I am sorry to be one of those people that complains, but is unable to contribute, but lack of fractional scaling has actually made me switch to KDE Plasma. On both my external monitor and my laptop's built-in display, I have to choose between a UI that is way too small or way too large. KDE Plasma supports fractional scaling out of the box, and doesn't make the text blurry. I really prefer GNOME, but I don't really have a choice. I would love to see this become a priority.
